To help needy people obtain food for Thanksgiving various
community service organizations, churches, synagogues, and
other non-profit organizations have united, sponsored by radio
station WAYE and WJZ-TV in cooperation with the governments
of Baltimore City and County to collect non-perishable food
items from Nov. 8 to 20 for distribution through established
church and community outreach programs.
Baltimore City and County fire stations and six National
Guard armories in Pikesville, Parkville, Towson, Glen Burnie,
Winchester, along with the 5th Regiment, are collection centers
for the program to complement existing food distribution programs. Established programs will operate as usual but donate
surpluses to the project.
Hopkins chaplain Chester Wickwire is the chairman of the
committee to organize church and synagogue collections. Groups
have been asked to designate this weekend as Harvest Festival
weekend. Volunteers will begin inventorying food for allocation
to community groups for distribution on the 18th, but the
Chaplain's Office will continue collections until the 20th. Individuals expressing a food need will be referred to the nearest participating organization.
For more information on participation call 396-1901 or
727-1177 or the Chaplain's Office at 338-8349.
On the 21st radio interviews will be held with representatives
of the Festival. Vashti McKenzie, General Manager of WAVE and
Phyllis Shelton, Community Relations Director, WJZ-TV are

Blitzer.

Anti-toxins,Contraceptives,And Carcinogens
BY STEVE EISENBERG
After scientists complete their
research, they publish their findings.
Either they are printed up in scientific
journals or they write entire books
concerning the research. Such books
which have eventually become best sellers
include James Watson's Double Helix and
Charles Darwin's Origin of Species.
Although Hopkins Professor Gary
Posner isn't a bestselling author, he has
published a book, An Introduction to
Synthesis Using Organocopper Reagants.
Two thousand copies have been printed,
and 1500 have been sold.
But Professor Posner, who received his Ph.D. in Chemistry from
Harvard University in 1968, prefers to
publish research papers. "Books are a
pain in the ass to write," commented
Posner. "If I write papers then I receive
invitations to give talks and to attend
international meetings." Thus far, 60 of
his papers have been published, but
before they are sent away for approval,
Posner must complete a tedious and
costly process.
The first step is to get an idea for
a project. "If I recognize a new method,"
noted Posner,"I look to see if I can apply
it to other chemicals such as a drug or a
pharmaceutical. Also, if I'm interested in
a certain class of molecules, I look at that
class and see how I can prepare them in a
new way. Both of these methods are
logical." He adds, "When I read journal
articles, I sometimes get insight into
bringing together things that are going
on.
After' deciding upon a research
topic, Posner goes to the library and "gets
a feeling of what has been done." He
writes up a proposal, usually between 20
and 50 pages long, that lists "the goals,
significance and considered possibilities
of the research, and also a literature
summary which includes references to
back up the proposal.:'
The proposal is then sent to

organizations which are usually government-affiliated, such as the National
Institutes of Health (NIH) and the
Department of Defense. "There's virtually no private industry support. Only five
percent of my research has been funded
by pharmaceutical companies or just by
scrounging around for money," noted
Posner.
Even with the government backing, fewer proposals are being supported.
"When I send in an application for a
project, it's ranked and depending on
how much money the institution has at
that time, a certain number of proposals
are chosen," said Posner.. "Today, even
some of the high-ranking' ones are being
turned down with all the budget cuts.
Reagan may do us in."
After the submission of the
proposal, a period of six months to a year
may pass which may cause "a project to
go stale." But Posner hasn't had that
happen to many of his projects. And
presently he is working on four different
research topics.
For three years, Posner and his lab
group, which includes four graduate
students and three post-doctorals, has
been developing new ways of preparing
known steroids which are organic compounds of thirty or more carbons. This
process is called "new synthetic methodology." "New procedures are being
developed to produce physiologically
active contraceptives," explained Posner.
In order to prepare new drugs,
Posner synthesizes compounds called
analogs which structurally resemble steroids. "Modifications are then made to
improve the analogs. The modified
steroids are then sent away to pharmaceutical companies to be checked," said
Posner.
Another goal listed by Posner in
his research proposal was to reduce the
number of steps in the synthesis of
steroids. "In the 1950s it took sixty
steps. In the last ten years it got down
to five," noted Posner. "Now we've

reduced it to one step." This aspect of
the research took a year.
Although Posner deals mostly
with his lab group, he also has given
research projects to undergraduates.
"Two of these have blossomed into major
projects," added Posner.
In 1970, while an undergraduate
was dealing with reactions on aluminum
oxide surfaces, Posner noticed something
odd about one of the reactions and is still
attempting to prove that the reactions on
aluminum oxide may mimic what is
thought to be the critical cancer step in
the body, alkylation, where a carcinogen
links to the DNA. The aluminum oxide
therefore might act as a template just as
DNA acts as a template in the cancer
process.
Posner is also participating in a
NIH-sponsored program project on cancer
along with five other professors. Since
obtaining a grant a year and a half ago,
the group has been trying to discover
"the molecular basis for effects of environmental pollutants." Within carcinogenic pollutants such as burning charcoal,
heated asphalt and smoke is polycyclic
aromatic hydrocarbons(PAH).
"What we want to know is how
PAH is metabolized in the body," said
Posner. "So Professor Selliger of the
Biology Department and myself are
making analogs to confirm what is going
on, to explore the metabolism. Rats are
used to show how PAH is broken down,
but we want to show the molecular
pathway. Therefore, we hypothesize what
the intermediate is and make it (the
analog). And if it coincides with the
prediction that we had made, that it is
dientiluninescent, then it is what we want.
Just this past week, we have synthesized a
compound that has exhibited chemilumiescent properties."
Once the intermediate is found
and the properties are the same as the
predictions, it will be fed to rats and
chemically reacted with DNA. Professor
Moudrianakis is handling this aspect

Dr. Posner
of the research, to determine if the
intermediate will damage the DNA.
"Cancer is the process whereby the DNA
is disrupted by carcinogens," added
Posner.
Professor Posner is also dealing
with the detoxification of toxic substances.(A year and a half ago the U.S.
Army granted a contract to him because
Posner had noticed that nerve gas was
among these toxic substances.) Though
nerve gas isn't used in Posner's lab,
simulants which are structurally similar
are substituted for the toxic substances.
Posner commented, "We're working out
the procedure on simulants in order to
detoxify substances. But I thought
the Army would be interested because of
the protection that we may need against
possible Russian chemical warfare."
When, and if, Professor Posner
completes his research on steroids,
cancer, toxic substances, et. al., he'll
publish his findings in scientific journals
in order to help other scientists. "They
want to know details concerning the
technique as soon as the paper is published," commented Posner.
When asked what he thought of
working for JHU,Posner replied,"I enjoy
teaching. I also enjoy the freedom of not
having a boss so I can pursue my own
ideas."
And pursuing his own ideas is
what Professor Posner does best.

isolation from neighboring Arab
countries under Sadat was in
part due to personal differences
between Sadat and the leaders of
those nations, according to
Blitzer.

concerning the research. Such books
which have eventually become best sellers
include James Watson's Double Helix and
Charles Darwin's Origin of Species.
Although Hopkins Professor Gary
Posner isn't a bestselling author, he has
published a book, An Introduction to
Synthesis Using Organocopper Reagants.
Two thousand copies have been printed,
and 1500 have been sold.
But Professor Posner, who received his Ph.D. in Chemistry from
Harvard University in 1968, prefers to
publish research papers. "Books are a
pain in the ass to write," commented
Posner. "If I write papers then I receive
invitations to give talks and to attend
international meetings." Thus far, 60 of
his papers have been published, but
before they are sent away for approval,
Posner must complete a tedious and
costly process.
The first step is to get an idea for
a project. "If I recognize a new method,"
noted Posner,"I look to see if I can apply
it to other chemicals such as a drug or a
pharmaceutical. Also, if I'm interested in
a certain class of molecules, I look at that
class and see how I can prepare them in a
new way. Both of these methods are
logical." He adds, "When I read journal
articles, I sometimes get insight into
bringing together things that are going
on.
After' deciding upon a research
topic, Posner goes to the library and "gets
a feeling of what has been done." He
writes up a proposal, usually between 20
and 50 pages long, that lists "the goals,
significance and considered possibilities
of the research, and also a literature
summary which includes references to
back up the proposal.:'
The proposal is then sent to

organizations which are usually government-affiliated, such as the National
Institutes of Health (NIH) and the
Department of Defense. "There's virtually no private industry support. Only five
percent of my research has been funded
by pharmaceutical companies or just by
scrounging around for money," noted
Posner.
Even with the government backing, fewer proposals are being supported.
"When I send in an application for a
project, it's ranked and depending on
how much money the institution has at
that time, a certain number of proposals
are chosen," said Posner.. "Today, even
some of the high-ranking' ones are being
turned down with all the budget cuts.
Reagan may do us in."
After the submission of the
proposal, a period of six months to a year
may pass which may cause "a project to
go stale." But Posner hasn't had that
happen to many of his projects. And
presently he is working on four different
research topics.
For three years, Posner and his lab
group, which includes four graduate
students and three post-doctorals, has
been developing new ways of preparing
known steroids which are organic compounds of thirty or more carbons. This
process is called "new synthetic methodology." "New procedures are being
developed to produce physiologically
active contraceptives," explained Posner.
In order to prepare new drugs,
Posner synthesizes compounds called
analogs which structurally resemble steroids. "Modifications are then made to
improve the analogs. The modified
steroids are then sent away to pharmaceutical companies to be checked," said
Posner.
Another goal listed by Posner in
his research proposal was to reduce the
number of steps in the synthesis of
steroids. "In the 1950s it took sixty
steps. In the last ten years it got down
to five," noted Posner. "Now we've

reduced it to one step." This aspect of
the research took a year.
Although Posner deals mostly
with his lab group, he also has given
research projects to undergraduates.
"Two of these have blossomed into major
projects," added Posner.
In 1970, while an undergraduate
was dealing with reactions on aluminum
oxide surfaces, Posner noticed something
odd about one of the reactions and is still
attempting to prove that the reactions on
aluminum oxide may mimic what is
thought to be the critical cancer step in
the body, alkylation, where a carcinogen
links to the DNA. The aluminum oxide
therefore might act as a template just as
DNA acts as a template in the cancer
process.
Posner is also participating in a
NIH-sponsored program project on cancer
along with five other professors. Since
obtaining a grant a year and a half ago,
the group has been trying to discover
"the molecular basis for effects of environmental pollutants." Within carcinogenic pollutants such as burning charcoal,
heated asphalt and smoke is polycyclic
aromatic hydrocarbons(PAH).
"What we want to know is how
PAH is metabolized in the body," said
Posner. "So Professor Selliger of the
Biology Department and myself are
making analogs to confirm what is going
on, to explore the metabolism. Rats are
used to show how PAH is broken down,
but we want to show the molecular
pathway. Therefore, we hypothesize what
the intermediate is and make it (the
analog). And if it coincides with the
prediction that we had made, that it is
dientiluninescent, then it is what we want.
Just this past week, we have synthesized a
compound that has exhibited chemilumiescent properties."
Once the intermediate is found
and the properties are the same as the
predictions, it will be fed to rats and
chemically reacted with DNA. Professor
Moudrianakis is handling this aspect

of the research, to determine if the
intermediate will damage the DNA.
"Cancer is the process whereby the DNA
is disrupted by carcinogens," added
Posner.
Professor Posner is also dealing
with the detoxification of toxic substances.(A year and a half ago the U.S.
Army granted a contract to him because
Posner had noticed that nerve gas was
among these toxic substances.) Though
nerve gas isn't used in Posner's lab,
simulants which are structurally similar
are substituted for the toxic substances.
Posner commented, "We're working out
the procedure on simulants in order to
detoxify substances. But I thought
the Army would be interested because of
the protection that we may need against
possible Russian chemical warfare."
When, and if, Professor Posner
completes his research on steroids,
cancer, toxic substances, et. al., he'll
publish his findings in scientific journals
in order to help other scientists. "They
want to know details concerning the
technique as soon as the paper is published," commented Posner.
When asked what he thought of
working for JHU,Posner replied,"I enjoy
teaching. I also enjoy the freedom of not
having a boss so I can pursue my own
ideas."
And pursuing his own ideas is
what Professor Posner does best.

Improved Blast Kick Off Second Indoor Season
BY STEVE EISENBERG
Tonight the Major Indoor
Soccer League kicks off with 12
of its 13 teams in action. One of
the dozen is Baltimore's own
Blast, which opens its season
against the Philadelphia Fever at
1:35 p.m.(WFBR).
A capacity crowd is expected at the Civic Center. According to general manager Mitch
Burke, nearly 8,000 tickets have
been distributed to the large
number of groups in the Baltimore soccer community, and
that figure also includes 1300
Blast season ticket holders. But
Burke is quick to reassure fans
there are several thousand good
seats still available.
"Because opening night was
sold out last season, the natural
tendency is to predict a sellout
again this year," Burke explained. "Ticket sales have been
great, and it's easy to become
excited and anticipate a full
house. But we don't want to be
premature. With the increased
capacity in the Civic Center this
year (from 10,400 to 11,100)
and the latest report from the
ticket office, those fans who
haven't purchased their tickets
for opening night won't be left
out in the cold — yet."

the cold this season, because last
year, they were only left out
in the cold when the season
came to an end. Under the
leadership of coach Kenny Cooper, the newly christened Blast
finished the regular season with
a 21-19 record, second in the
Atlantic Division and runner-up
to the New York Arrows. After
disposing of the Cleveland Force
in a best-of-three quarterfinal
playoff series, the Blast advanced to the MISL semifinal.
